text:
it appears tomcat uses sun.tools.javac.Main for compiling jsp's
and servlets

according to java documentation
http://java.sun.com/products/jdk/faq/faq-sun-packages.html
sun.* packages are not guaranteed to be supported across platforms
and should not be used.
creator: tchao@lobby7.com

text:
A Java compiler is required for using JSP.  sun.tools.javac.Main is the
interface provided by Sun to use their Java compiler in-process.  Until
Sun provides a standard API for this, there is no alternative to
using it unless you compile out-of-process.
creator: Larry.Isaacs@sas.com

text:
why does the compile need to happen in-process?
what's wrong with calling java.lang.Runtime.exec() and using the commandline 
javac?

i understand that under the sun jvm sun.tools.javac.Main is the only way to 
compile something in-process, but the point is, this is not a supported feature 
and not guaranteed to work across jvm implementations. if tomcat is supposed to 
be a platform independant servlet engine then i believe it needs a better way 
of dealing with javac. at the very least, sun.tools.javac.* should be packaged 
and distributed with tomcat so that a person with just the jre or another jvm 
implementation installed can still use tomcat.
creator: tchao@lobby7.com

text:
You can plug any java compiler, via a simple adapter. Jikes adapter is provided.
Since each compile has it's own flags/options, you need the adapter - there is
no standard interface or options even for exec().
